assessment.title: Anatomy and Direction of the Skeletal Organs

body.p: Knees and ankles are articulations in the legs. From the knee, the ankle is in which direction?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The ankle is distal to the knee.
Correct. Distal means away from the trunk. The ankles and knees are on the limbs. The ankles are further away from the trunk of the body than the knees.

Incorrect. Sometimes the ankle can be in front of the knee (such as while you are walking or sitting down), but when using anatomical directional terms, we always imagine the person in an upright, still, standing position. Anterior indicates toward the front of the body.
This is not the best answer. Inferior does mean toward the lower part of the body, but distal is the most appropriate answer here because the limbs are separate from the axis of the body.

hint.p: The ankle is further from the axis of the body than the knee.

body.p: The skull bones are also articulated; you will learn more about the articulations of the skull in a later section of the course. What direction is the skull from the rest of the skeleton?

feedback.p: Correct. The skull is the top-most structure of the skeleton.
Incorrect. You have the right idea, but the opposite direction.
Incorrect. Medial is toward the center of the body.
Incorrect. Lateral is away from the center of the body.

hint.p: The skull is at the top of the body.
